title: This is the best compromise I can find
content: First off, unlike the other review currently up right now I don't find myself making any typing errors that I can blame on the keyboard. I use this mostly for work and as such I type A LOT, pretty much all I do is write e-mails all day, chat with coworkers and do some small amount of programming. Programming of course can't have typos in it, otherwise things simply don't work. Likewise, my e-mails and instructions to other people are very technical. A typo could make all the difference in the world with what I am trying to convey. If this keyboard did not type 100% correctly for me then I would be sending it back. That simply is not the case. If you're wondering; I am connected via Bluetooth to my HP laptop that runs Windows 10. My laptop is line-of-sight from the keyboard; no physical obstructions between the two and they're maybe a grand total of three feet from each other. Anyway, so that covers probably the reliability in typing, what about the rest? Well personally this is the only keyboard I have seen that comes close to ticking all of my boxes, both in needs and wants: -Mechanical -Wireless -84-key -Aluminum deck -USB-C So why the compromise? Well, they aren't Cherry switches, but at this price you won't get those. Nevertheless, I don't have any complaints with these Gatereon switches myself. They're very smooth and feel great to type on. Can't say I have much experience with Reds at all though, but I like it. Secondly, while it's USB-C they stuck the connector on the side of the keyboard. Who does that? It's weird. Not that I plan on using it plugged in, if I need to recharge it then I'll just plug it in overnight, but still... Lastly, the wireless. It'd be nice if it had a dongle transceiver like Logitech products since they work oh so well but alas it uses Bluetooth. As I said before, I use this for work, I don't game but I do intend to do a very tiny bit once every never. Having said that I have seen enough times where this keyboard has had to catch up with my typing (and it's never missed a key I've pressed either), however infrequently that happens, even if it were just once an hour it'd be enough to frustrate a gamer. Then again, if you bought this for gaming, you are only fooling yourself if you think it, or any other wireless keyboard, would be good for that. Edit: one last thing worth mentioning for the BT wireless is that it is set, by default, to a power-saving mode. That is that for ten minutes of inactivity the keyboard goes to sleep, but maintains connection. It's never had an issue waking up. Related to that, whenever I start up it connects immediately and flawlessly, never had any issue with it connecting it just works (no power cycling or going to Settings, etc.) But! It IS USB-C! Even if it's in a weird position. It IS wireless, even if it plays catch up sometimes. It IS mechanical, even if it's not the gold standard of Cherry switches. Also, it IS 84-key: inbetween a 60% and a TKL if I had to describe it. It DOES have an aluminum deck as well, which feels nice to the touch, machined very well, and just gives it a nice, unique property. Also, it has lights, if you like RGB lights. I don't really care for that feature so I leave it off anyway. It's only been a few short days I have been typing on this but so far I love it. Not sure how long the battery will last but if I can remember to I will report what it lasted me of what is basically day in and day out of typing full time. tl;dr: I love this keyboard, it does everything I wanted out of a wireless, mechanical keyboard, but I would just fix a couple things here and there. Edit 10/07/19: I just now noticed that the LED on the side has started to blink which indicates it's battery level is no more than 15%. Also, I did lie and ended up turning on the backlit LEDs to see if I liked them and I do. Mine were fairly low consumption as I only kept them on the second lowest brightness setting, they were solid red, and not reactive to any sort of input just were lit at their set brightness constantly. I also had the normal power saving mode left on (ten minutes of inactivity and it sleeps, IIRC) and I never once switched off the keyboard. I did keep my laptop on the whole time, minus the first weekend where it was turned off, so nothing for the keyboard to connect to anyway. So from receiving it on 09/19/19 I used it every weekday for work where I am at my desk, typing the majority of the time (to be fair I also do a fair bit of research as well and do have phone calls, meetings, etc. where I am generally not typing). I would count today and the day I got it as half days, so it's about 13, eight hour days of steady usage before it got to 15% (the light may have been on longer, but I only noticed it now). Take it for what you will. I am going to see if it can last the next hour and a half before I stop working so I don't have to bother charging it. I mean, I got it because I didn't want to see cables. If I only have to charge it every couple of weeks after work then I don't mind one bit.

title: I was not expecting to fall in love with the keyboard, but I did!
content: Here's the story from the beginning. When I was researching keyboards, I ended up purchasing the Logitech mx keys (which I still have back in its original packaging). I used the mx keys for a day of work and absolutely loved it. It's wireless, comfortable key strokes, has a numpad (for data entry), and I can switch it seamlessly between my work laptop and my macbook. But, that same night, I ended up stumbling upon an advertisement for a mechanical keyboard (curse modern day advertising). Before buying the Logitech mx keys, the idea didn't strike me that I would possibly want a mechanical keyboard. I felt like my research was incomplete. I needed to look into this. I ended up researching a couple mechanical keyboards like Ducky, Leopold, and Razer. I never owned a mechanical keyboard before and wasn't sure what to look for. Then I found the Keychron K2 on Amazon, and it just really stuck out to me. It was wireless, supported multi device pairing, but did not have a numpad. After reading some reviews on tech sites and watching some Youtube videos on it, I found the opinions very mixed. The biggest complaint was about the height/thickness of the keyboard and how unergonomic it was. Alot of reviewers mentioned wrist pain while using the K2, and the need for a wrist rest when using it. So I order the K2, with the weird intent that I was probably going to return it. I was mentally prepared to experience wrist pain and be sorely disappointed by the lack of a numpad. Plus, I already was enamored with the Logitech mx keys I just bought. I genuinely didn't think I would be caught in a love triangle like this. My Keychron K2 came in today, from first glance it is a beautiful keyboard, minimal and I love the grey. The build quality is great, it has some weight to it and atleast feels expensive! I ended up using it for about 4 hours for work. And my goodness, what an absolute joy to work on. I got mine with the Gateron blue switches. From just a typist's perspective, the clickity clackity is incredibly stress relieving. I feel like my typing speed is faster. I did not think I would enjoy using this keyboard for work, but I absolutely LOVE IT. I didn't even think twice about the missing numpad, I think I'm already over it. Also, my wrists are not sore, and I don't have a wrist rest! I'm already looking for external numpads I can use just for data entry projects. Obviously, everyone is different. Before buying a mechanical keyboard I highly recommend researching the type of switch you would want to get it with. I love the gateron blue switches, but not everyone likes the clickity clack - my girlfriend especially hates it! If you want a keyboard that's more quiet, look into red or brown switches which are also very popular! Lastly, if you decide to buy the Keychron K2, keep the packaging in case your wrists start hurting from using it. For some folks this could be a deal breaker! As of right now, I'm still in a quandary. I typed this review with my K2, but I might end up returning it to stay with the Logitech mx keys. Or I might return the Logitech.... I don't know! Can I just keep both keyboards??? UPDATE 5/26/20: After a couple days of intense deliberation, I decided to keep.... the K2. Even though I'm in a job where I work with a lot of excel and data entry, the joy of typing on this keyboard just couldn't be matched on the Logitech MX keys. Plus, the minimal design of the TKL just looks amazing on my desk. If in the next couple days or weeks I find myself really missing a numeric keypad, I'll consider buying an external one. I should also mention that I still do not feel wrist strain from using this keyboard for a prolonged period. This Keychron K2 is truly a pleasant surprise for me. But to be honest, I probably could've just gone with the plastic white backlight version. I rarely use backlighting on keyboards in general, it was never a need for me. Besides that, because the keyboard is so thick, I can barely see the lights from my viewing angle when typing. I won't exchange the one I have though, I do like the aluminum body and the darker keycaps it came with. I'm already emotionally attached (This is my first mechanical keyboard). I do have one complaint about the K2 I received: The USB C port looks to be misaligned, its a bit crooked and I can see inside the keyboard. Going to email support if this is an issue, I might just be able to open the keyboard and pop it into place. Still charges normally but it does bother me a little.

title: Perfect in Theory, Flawed in Execution
content: I was so excited about this keyboard because it fit a very specific set of requirements that I had: Mac and PC compatibility, wireless connectivity (which alone narrows your choices down substantially with mechanical keyboards), and a compact footprint. Needless to say, after hours of research this seemed like the perfect solution. When it arrived, I was impressed by the build quality. While the metal only extends to the edges of the frame, it's very nice and substantial-feeling overall. Pairing it to my MacBook for work was a breeze and maintaining the media key functionality was great. The trouble started when I attempted to connect it to my PC. While pairing went fine, things started to fall apart when I tried using the keyboard. The first sign that something was amiss was when I attempted to log into Windows and none of my inputs registered. I ended up connecting it to my PC via the cable just so it would recognize my keystrokes. I opened WordPad and did some testing only to be met with an absolute mess. Dozens of duplicate entries (You wanted one "f"? How about 52?) and missed entries. Mind you, I have a pretty small desk (42"x24") so I didn't think the Bluetooth signal would be an issue when the keyboard was only 18" from my PC, but sure enough, it seemed to make all the difference. Since Bluetooth is built into my motherboard, the only solution seemed to be keeping the keyboard as close as possible to the PC. If I kept it within around 1', performance improved to a satisfactory level - still an errant duplicate or missed keystroke here and there, but much better. I reached out to Keychron's Support team to see if there was anything else I should try. It took four days to get an initial response. I reset the keyboard as instructed but this yielded the same results. I also provided a video of the behavior as they requested. They responded two days later asking me if the reset fixed the issue (I already told them it hadn't) and asked me if the problem was that I couldn't connect the keyboard to devices (it wasn't). After another three days, their most recent reply was effectively “Yes, your Bluetooth range is apparently limited. Here's $15 off your order. Sorry." This is where I gave up. If I'm going to have a wireless keyboard, I'd prefer that its functionality not be dictated by where I choose to place it on my small desk. I fully understand that my PC is probably part of the issue here, but having Bluetooth performance issues at a distance of 2' is quite poor, especially when I have a Bluetooth mouse that's working just fine in the same conditions. Maybe their continued use of Bluetooth 3.0 in their devices has something to do with it too, who knows. While I'm complaining, I'd also like to point out that the labelling of the switches (one for Mac/iOS or Windows/Android and another for Bluetooth, Off, and Cable) is terrible. Tiny, embossed letters on a black surface are virtually illegible in anything less than direct lighting. Granted, you'll quickly learn where each switch needs to be based on feel but if you're still learning, bring a flashlight. Oh how I wanted to love you, Keychron K2. I really did.

title: Bad quality control, info on battery replacement and other stuff from taking it apart
content: I love this keyboard now, but it arrived with a few issues that were unacceptable. For context I own several mechanical keyboards and have built a few from scratch so this isn't my first rodeo. One of the switches (the one for the R key) consistently snagged if I pressed it just slightly off center to the right. The snag was incredibly bad and made typing on it just horrible. I had to open up the board and solder on another switch. I could have returned it but a lot of other reviews also mentioned issues that reek of quality control problems and I didn't want to risk trying another one. EDIT: the right arrow key snags too after I went through and tested it again. Luckily it seemed to be a clearance issue between the switch casing and the keycap stem, so I shaved down the offending edge on the keycap stem and that mostly mitigated the issue. I am fairly certain it's the switch casing itself as every key I tried snagged on the upper edge of the stem. Guess I'm replacing this one too, sigh. Another issues is that the keycaps weren't all the same height per row. My F5 key is noticeably (like a millimeter) taller than the rest of the row that it was on. Also the keycaps in the left column aren't the standard order (home pageup, pagedown, end) and there's no way to do a hardware remap if I want to change that. Also, not sure if this is intentional on this keycap profile, but my function row is also noticeably shorter than my row 2. This isn't an issue for me but it's worth mentioning. When I opened up the board there were a few bits and pieces of black plastic or metal shaving that were inside the case. Think they might need to replace the vacuum on their milling machine. One super big issue I have with the board is that Keychron doesn't sell replacement batteries or give any information at all . When I had the keyboard open I noticed a giant piece of isolation tape over the battery. Why? That doesn't seem necessary on a battery at all. I suspected that Keychron didn't want us to see what was under there, and sure enough information was printed on the battery under the tape (the tape took off most of the ink so it was really faded too, ugh). Back of the battery is glued into the case by the way. Here's what was printed on it, which luckily includes voltage, amperage, and wattage information: - HX 606090  3.7V  14.8Wh + NY  4000mAh  20HJL And the approximate dimensions of the battery for those that want to replace it: left to right width: 92.2mm (there's a little bit more left to right clearance) top to bottom height: 61.3mm (there's isn't much clearance for anything taller) deepness: 5.8mm (there's enough clearance for a battery maybe up to 9mm thick) I don't know if hiding the battery information is intentional (on the board itself, on amazon, and on Keychron's website), but the result is still pretty anti-consumer. A lot of other keyboard manufacturers do it too. At least the battery has a plug so you can disconnect it from the PCB easily. Keychron: please sell replacement batteries or give information about it on your website. I would much rather buy a battery direct from you than find a replacement elsewhere or buy a whole new keyboard if I still want to use the wireless in a few years. If you do this you'll be better than the majority of keyboard manufacturers. Okay, onto the actual board itself. If you don't get quality control issues I think it's a fantastic board. The backlighting options are phenomenal and the controls for it are pretty intuitive. The stabilizers on the board had plenty of lube on them out of the box. The switches probably could have used some more lubrication but that's a lot of work and I don't expect that on a keyboard this price. Gateron reds are still significantly more smooth than cherry reds though. Aluminum side plates are solid and very premium feeling. The screws holding the aluminum plates on seem to be some kind of self tapping torx head screw. The ones that hold the switchplate and pcb to the case are some kind of phillips head screw (threads are too wide to be m2 or m3 so I'm not sure what they are). The screws good quality though so they won't need to be replaced. The flip out feet seem fine. Not the most premium feeling but I doubt they'll break from regular usage. A lot of people don't like the recess for the usb-c port but I like it. If you have a cable that fits it prevents the cable from flexing too far in any direction. The mode switches next to the port are high quality and I like them. Wireless bluetooth latency is fine for most things. It is noticeable in games but I doubt most people would notice it in office use. Final thoughts: I love this thing, and it's a 75% keyboard that fits my needs. It sounds and feels amazing for the price too. However there's just some quality control issues that seem to be pretty commonly mentioned, and whole thing about the battery. Would I recommend this keyboard to people? Yeah, if you can accept that you might have to rma the first one. Wish there were more options for 75% keyboards in this price bracket but this keyboard is pretty okay.

title: Keychron is doing it right
content: I have searched long for a keyboard that has almost no compromise on the features I need, without building a custom. As a software developer, I have grown used to the home and end keys, but as a gamer I wanted a keyboard smaller than a tenkeyless. I wanted dedicated F-keys, I preferred dedicated arrow keys, and RGB is something I crave more than I should. The Keychron K2 has it all, and then some. I wasn't seeking out a wireless keyboard, but having that option is amazing when I consider I would have paid the same or more for a keyboard without this feature. The lighting options are numerous and vivid, some of the best RGB I have seen, although sadly it doesn't have software to individually control each key at this time. I am impressed with Gateron switches. I typically prefer Cherry MX Clears, but for my gaming rig I wanted to try out linears so I have a red switch variant. I also chose the aluminum rails, which make the keyboard feel like an absolute tank. There is a lot to like with the Keychron K2, but there are a few key downsides. Firstly, the keycaps on mine are not very good quality. The page says they should be double-shot not, but I don't think mine came with double-shot as the legends are wearing on some keys. This is compounded by the difficulty in replacing the full keycap set, since many of the keys are uniquely shaped/sized for this form factor. The shift key, and the home, end, pgup, and pgdn keys are all abnormal sizes compared with a fullsize keyboard. My second gripe with this keyboard, which I assume extends to Keychron's full wireless lineup, is that it takes multiple seconds for the keyboard to start accepting key inputs after my login screen appears--even though I am using it as a wired keyboard with Bluetooth turned off. They really should take the time to correct this in a firmware patch. Last issue I have, and this could so easily be corrected, is that there isn't a single page on their site or in a manual with all the possible hotkeys to control the keyboard. A reddit page exists that has most, but even it is missing some. Why not have your firmware dev just make a list of all the hotkey combos so they can be in one place? This next item isn't an issue, but more of a request to Keychron: please do invest, as I think you already are, in software engineers to create software for your keyboards. They are amazing products and they deserve to have software controls and keymapping available. I spent most of this review talking about what I didn't like, and that is because a good keyboard shouldn't stick out. When I interact with this keyboard, it is an extension of my mind. I sometimes stutter as the layout isn't familiar, even after months, when aiming for home, end, or delete--but they keyboard itself is almost flawless in execution. I will be buying more Keychron keyboards in the future, and potentially leaving their competition on the shelves.

author: Nufangld

title: Fantastic keyboard. Such an upgrade from the Magic Keyboard
content: I purchased the K2 with blue switches and aluminum body. This thing is amazing! The tactile feedback and the clickity clack of the blue switches is so soothing and satisfying when I type. The additional light show (RGB) is entertaining, albeit occasionally distracting. Luckily you can change the patterns and also opt to turn it off completely with the simple press of a button. The keyboard is able to switch seamlessly between Mac/OS and Windows with the flick of a side switch. It can also be used over bluetooth or with its included cable. Lastly, it comes with a keycap remover and some additional keys (like the alt cover for Windows), should you decide against having the orange escape button as pictured. If you are the current owner of an Apple Magic Keyboard or are only using your stock low profile laptop board, this will be a huge upgrade. My typing is faster, more accurate, and I cannot stress enough how satisfying the tactile feedback of a mechanical keyboard is. Once you use it for a day you'll never want to go back to a stock keyboard again.

title: Amazon is TERRIBLE, Keychron is great!
content: I'm struggling with ordering keychron k2 (gatreon brown). I placed an order for brown switches and got red switches. I understand, some mess up happened at the warehouse probably. author: Ajay Kedia

title: Not as good as I had hoped for
content: My biggest problem with this keyboard is the auto sleep feature. I can understand the need and would be fine if it "woke up" smoothly and raring to go after its nap. But seems like everytime my keychron takes its powernap, I need to really coax and cajole it back to work. I have tried disabling auto sleep (which in itself isn't very intuitive and it's also not clear to me whether it's disabled or not). You are supposed to press a key combination for 4 seconds to disable the feature. I have tried and it doesn't seem to disable auto sleep. Or maybe I have tried a few times out of frustration of not getting any feedback from the keyboard and therefore I don't know if I disabled it or ended up reenabling it a second time. As a result, every time during a restart, it's a struggle and instead of being productive with my work, I'm here at Amazon venting my frustration. To get it to respond after it's sleep, I have to turn the bluetooth on and off a few times, try the bluetooth coupling key combination, try the cable mode, but I don't know what is the magical action that brings the elusive "Keyboard connected" message on the screen. This struggle has traumatized me so much that during some lengthy zoom calls, I randomly fiddle with my keyboard just to keep it alive. What I want from a good mechanical keyboard isn't some fancy backlighting ---- it's reliability. And that's exactly where this product fails, you don't want to be thinking hard about a peripheral and wondering when it might fail. It should be functional when needed. Super frustrated with this product.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
author: V J

title: Mine won't connect via Bluetooth, but good with cable
content: Last update on 4/6/2021: I’ve gotten the newer version of the K2 that is hotswappable, because I wanted to try new switches and I could never get this one to work in Bluetooth mode. This one still works brilliantly in wired mode. I seem to have gotten a unit with some type of Bluetooth flaw that no amount of troubleshooting (firmware, factory resets, etc.) could fix, but for those who are looking to buy this older model of the K2, I want to say that when I tried draining the battery completely and then charging it fully, it took more than two days of me leaving the keyboard on with sleep mode disabled and the RGB light show running at full brightness nonstop. If you use the K2 wirelessly, you can probably expect to get a lot of use out of it before recharging. The typing experience is immeasurably more comfortable than the MacBook's butterfly keyboard. It feels substantial, it looks as cool as I hoped it would, and I appreciate that it's Mac-compatible out of the box. Getting the Gateron blue switches was the right choice for me because I'm not typing in a room with anyone else, but for anyone considering them, know that the sound of these blue switches is loud and proud. It sounds deeper but also louder when I use PBT keycaps instead of the ones that came with the board, which are attractive but prone to developing shiny spots from your fingers. Original review: After watching several video reviews and reading reviews online, I thought this was The One. Its combination of looks and build quality, as well as its lower price, convinced me to buy. Unfortunately, I was able to use the keyboard for only a few hours in Bluetooth mode. I turned it off for the night, thinking that was the right thing to do when I wouldn't be using it for about nine or ten hours. Then I woke up yesterday, turned it on, and have been unable to get my devices to see it ever since. After many hours of trying every recommended solution short of updating the firmware (which I'll have to do on a PC when I can get to one), I've given up on being able to use it in Bluetooth mode. I've ordered a converter to connect the cable to my MacBook Pro, but it won't arrive for at least another day, so I just have a nice-looking light display at the moment. For the few hours of use I got out of it in Bluetooth mode, I really enjoyed the typing experience. The keyboard feels solid and I love the way the keys click. It's got a pretty bunch of light shows. It was easy to pair with both the MacBook Pro and the iPhone XS Max the first time, but that's it.

author: Cindy S.

title: Nice to use keyboard with a clean design.
content: 12/1/19-Initial impressions First off I picked up this keyboard with the black friday "price drop". I use the quotation marks because looking at the price history (using the honey extension) of this keyboard, it appears that the price was bumped up from ~$80 to $100 at the beginning of November and then dropped back down to $80 to give the appearance of a deal. Not a huge fan of this, but it does happen a lot on black friday so be aware. Overall, I am happy for the price that I paid for the keyboard. The build quality is solid! It's heavier than I expected (a good thing), probably due to the aluminum and battery. The keys are easy to switch out for windows or mac. There are plenty of lighting effects and the color can be selected for most of them which is fun. I have been using it to type up my thesis for a few hours already and am still getting used to it, but so far it seems comfortable and I haven't noticed any mistypes (at least not more than normal). I only have one complaint in terms of the quality and that is that my space bar has a small bump/rough spot in the finish of the space bar. I wouldn't mind all that much, but it is right where my thumb hits so it's noticeable.  I'd like to switch out the spacebar, but knowing me, I'll probably just live with it. I plan to update this review after I spend more time with the keyboard, I'll update on battery life and long term comfort and any issues that might pop up. 1/7/2020 Small update, keyboard battery finally died for the first time. I use it almost every day (writing a thesis RIP) and i do have the lights on most of the time. Keyboard still in great shape, fun to type on, not too loud.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
author: alex

title: I was happy with it . . . for a while
content: I've had this keyboard for about 7 months. I like the feel of the keyswitches, the RBG backlighting works well, and it is compact.  Battery life is also quite good. For the first six months i had it, the bluetooth connectivity worked reliably. Now, however, it has become flaky. When the keyboard has been idle for a period, it goes into a sleep mode to preserve the battery; when you press a key, it wakes up, the RBG lights turn on again, and it reconnects over Bluetooth. That last part -- reconnecting over Bluetooth when it wakes up -- was the part that worked fine for the first six months. Now, it often will not reconnect.  (I press a key to wake it up, the RBG lighting turns on, and it appears that the keyboard is ready to go -- but keypresses simply do not register on the computer; my computer's Bluetooth controls confirm that it is not connected.)  I have tried a couple of solutions to this problem when it occurs: switching the keyboard from Bluetooth mode to Wired mode and then back again; and deleting the profile from my computer and repairing it.  Switching modes only works sometimes; deleting the profile and repairing always works but it is a royal pain.  As a result, I can only recommend this keyboard for use as a wired keyboard.

author: uesjd

title: Great mechanical keyboard satisfies a demanding user
content: Lots of travel, clacky, accurate. That's what I demand in a keyboard, and this delivers. I type extremely fast and need a keyboard that will keep up. This keyboard leaves nothing to be desired in performance. Ergonomically, there are some challenges. I recommend a wrist support depending on your seating position (vertical distance between your arms and the desk). I knew what I was buying, so nothing against the company or the keyboard itself. The markings on the keycaps are just big enough for me. I'd personally prefer slightly larger text, but it's by no means worthy of bumping the star rating down. The unit has some weight to it. It won't be sliding around all over your desk, which tends to happen with cheaper compact keyboards. I'd say this thing weighs around 2 lbs. Overall build quality is excellent. Lighting is pretty cool on this thing. The LED's can get pretty bright and are easily dimmed if desired. Lots of patterns will keep you mildly entertained throughout the day. The only extremely mild complaint I have with the backlighting is that depending on what pattern or color you use, the escape key text gets washed out. But considering it's the only red key on the board (unless you swap out the lighting key with the extra included) it's still abundantly clear where esc is. I use this keyboard on both my Mac and my PC (I just use the PC/Mac toggle switch between the two). I can't comment on battery life between recharges yet. Bluetooth connectivity is rock solid. I have not had the keyboard disconnect or lag. Keep in mind the keyboard will disconnect and there will be a single keystroke delay if you keep sleep mode enabled (on by default, 10 minute timeout).

author: Steven

title: Very impressed so far
content: I've been using the same IBM model M keyboard since 2003. It was made in 1997 and it's been with me ever since through countless moves. It has yet to fail. When it comes to mechanical keyboards I'm quite the snob and purist. However, I've been wanting something smaller for work and play.  I researched mechanical keyboards and I didn't want to spend the time learning and building one. I ran into this Keychron keyboard through the reviews and it had good reviews. I use function keys and special keys quite a lot, and it won't take long to get muscle memory on the new layout. I'm not a fan of RGB, but I do like that the caps lock key lights up red if I accidentally enable it. The keys have the perfect feel when typing. It has the nostalgic sound of keys clicking as you type. You can change this by purchasing little o rings separately. It also has a good weight to it probably due to the battery. author: Rick

title: Coders/Programmers - Pay attention to the right shift key, and the placement of the left CMD key!
content: This keyboard is great. The build quality is solid and it looks way better than I thought - the outline of each letter on the keycap is really sharp. I used to use the Magic Keyboard before this. One thing that immediately became clear, though, is how much I relied on the right shift key being longer and the left CMD key is much further to the left than on the Magic Keyboard. It's a bit uncomfortable, but looking at other keyboards, it does seem to be more standardized, with the Magic Keyboard being the exception rather than the rule!

author: aflashyrhetoric

title: Just hype... not really... thank goodness...
content: I have been using the Cooler Master blue-switch Quick Fire Rapid mechanical keyboard for a while. I initially purchased it for my windows dedicated gaming PC, which I sold about three years ago. Overall, I've been happy with it, but it is the Windows version and over the last couple of years I've been using it on my 2020 MacBook Pro. Lately, I've been wanting the dedicated keys specific to MAC on a mechanical keyboard (e.g. brightness, volume, command key, option, etc.). Politically, I'm not an Apple fan and wish they would stick to what they do best. However, they have solid hardware, software, customer support, which I prefer for pursuing my second masters degree over the Windows platform. I've been using Apple for years... HomePods, iPhones, MacBooks, iPads and so forth. I opted to try the brown keys from my blues... great choice for quick touch typists (you aren't heavy-handed mashing keys...even so, this will fit the bill). With the blue switches, I have to be quite a bit more precise with my keypresses due to the mechanical feedback/actuation. I often miss key presses because I do not pressing the keys down far enough due to the resistance require for that extra click feedback... so I opted for the brown switches because I like the feedback of the blues, but wanted something that required less effort like the reds.. I'd take a blue switch over red anyway... just not my thing as I like the feedback with slight auditory feedback... blue are just way too loud and disruptive when others are in the surrounding area. I ended up getting the K2 with brown switches. Perfect match for typing papers... not too loud, but I get that satisfying clacking sound without having to get past that "hard click." Blues also make it a challenge to double press keys (two of the same letters back to back e.g. "tt" in the word "letters). This makes my typing much more effortless while still getting that ever so slight and satisfying feedback (extremely subtle). I'm in love. Do I like the blue switches, oh ya, do I like the browns, I'm in heaven and probably should have opted for this switch-set long ago. I see myself using this keyboard for long nights typing 15-25 page papers as well as gaming as I did with my blue switches. I like the loud feedback/click of the blue, but I get that somewhat with browns and I don't have to work as hard or be as accurate with my typing since it doesn't require as much pressure with my key presses. My typing is much more on point when writing papers, extended emails, etc. Form factor wise, the K2 it is very compact. Awesome due to my restricted desktop space and I don't need the # keypad. When I read reviews, many mentioned the large and elevated front lip area... ughh, I understand what they are saying... ergonomically, no issues on my end with the elevated feet on the top side extended. It is nearly perfect... even without the top side being elevated. I'm pretty sure this company likely took this into consideration when designing the product, but it may not be for everyone (the thicker front frame area). Is the hype true? I'd say so. Look at all the positive feedback on Amazon. The company has been pretty successful. The keyboard was nearly $100 for me and I'm glad I decided to just spend the money to give it a try. The design is simplistic and looks great (professional environments and for gamers... wonderful compromise if that's what you call it). The RGB backlighting is fun and interesting, but not a necessity. I enjoy it overall. Would I recommend this keyboard to my peers and family? Without hesitation. I'd recommend it to my gamer friends as well as working professionals... and those who just want a keyboard that is comfortable. For those that just want something to plug and play... not for the money... e.g. my mother who will sit on Youtube and Facebook finger jamming away at keys. Summarily... get this keyboard if you want a solid typing and gaming experience from a quality product... for the average person finger-pricking at the keys... just go to Walmart and get a $5-10 keyboard. If your here looking at reviews... it is for a reason... you want a descent keyboard and are willing to spend the money... I'd say do it without hesitation. I purchased mine thinking I'd try it and simply send it back if it gave me any reasonable doubt... it is staying and I wouldn't hesitate to purchase it again if need be... -------14OCT20------- Just wanted to emphasize after owning this keyboard for a brief period now that it is one of the best typing experiences I have ever had since my 20+ years of having to type on keyboards... I have 3 degrees, so I've done a lot of typing in regards to my life experience. I without a doubt would recommend this to family, friends for personal, school, and professional use without hesitation. The keyboard is a steal at around $80-100. The build quality and color scheme are outstanding as well and will fit most any environment... looks professional as well as fun with the addition of RGB that can be set to just white. This keyboard is great for gamers as well... just a no nonsense, compact, aesthetically pleasing keyboard that performs flawlessly. I know I mentioned a lot of this previously, but I can't emphasize enough how wonderful this keyboard has been since I constantly have to use it day in and day out.

author: Saint04

title: It's a good keyboard.
content: Pros: Fair price Low noise (for a mechanical keyboard) Handles 3 BT devices well Good battery life Good Mac emulation and interoperability (including media control keys) Small size makes it easily portable, but it's also very physically stable Cons: No tactile confirmation of key-press (Gateron Brown v2) Limited to a preset selection of backlight settings The "bumps" on the F and J keys could be raised a bit more Occasional key-bounce (I think) No obvious way to check battery level I'm a programmer and touch typist. I got the K2 with Gateron Brown v2 keys to use with two Macbook Pros and my Android phone. Mission accomplished on all fronts. Switching among devices is simple and quick. I thought about getting the Blue keys for their better tactile feedback, but I don't want to raise a racket when I type (which is all day). I've been using the K2 since I received it three weeks ago and only recharged it a couple of days ago. I'm not sure I had to, but anything over a couple of weeks on a single charge is all I might possibly need. I've been using Macbook Pro's keyboard comfortably enough for many years, but the transition to the K2's Gateron Brown v2 keys only took a couple of days before I was mostly at ease with it. (I have an Apple Magic Bluetooth Trackpad beside the Keychron connected to my main laptop.) The K2's small footprint is perfect for my desk's keyboard drawer, even with the trackpad beside it, providing much better ergonomics than using the laptop's own keyboard. The only thing that still trips me up from time to time is that the K2's left-hand command key is slightly to the left of where my left thumb expects to find it, so I sometimes hit command-space with my thumb when I mean to use the command key for something else. The arrow keys' location is something else I have to pay attention to. I'll get used to it. Two major differences between Macbook's native keyboard layout and the K2's are the location of the "fn" key and the presence of the "del" key. The K2 has both a backspace and delete key, while the Macbook has only a "delete" key that performs a "backspace" function unless the fn key is pressed. K2's fn-backspace combo also performs a delete operation, but because the fn key is between the right command and control keys (rather than on the left side of the keyboard), I've been training myself to use the K2's "del" key instead. One thing I love, since I'm in vi most of the day, is having a full-sized, first-class escape key. (I love that thing, and if you're a heavy user of vi, you'll understand that.) I'm told Keychron is working on their own customization software for the K2. I'm really looking forward to that in the hope that it will give me considerably more control over the RBG LED backlight setup. I'm using the "red throb" setting now because I prefer an understated backlight, but what I'd like is for the red backlight to be constant rather than throbbing. I can find no such predefined setting. I work in a dimly lit environment (by choice), so on those occasions when I need to look at the keyboard to find a function or media control key, I do need a backlight to see the keys. I stand by the pros and cons I listed at the top of this review, but I would definitely recommend this keyboard to someone with needs similar to mine. I'm very demanding of my keyboard's performance, and this one has been a game-changer for me. I wish I'd been able to make this switch a long time ago. If the K2's key layout were more faithful to that of the Macbook Pro, I'd have given it 5 stars, even with the "cons" I've listed. (I might well be in a very small minority who care this much about that.) Oh. The K2's Android support was maybe a 2nd- or 3rd-tier reason I chose it, but the Android mode works great. I've only used it with my phone a few times for evaluation purposes, but it works very well. If I need to write anything significant on my phone, I'll definitely go grab this super-portable keyboard to do that. If it matters, my phone is a Pixel 2 running Android 11. Bottom Line: Buy this keyboard!

title: Awesome lighting and a very comfortable mac native keyboard
content: The media could not be loaded. I've been looking for a mac minded mechanical keyboard for a while and just stumbled upon the Keychron brand. The lighting was probably the least important factor for me in choosing a mechanical keyboard but I was really blown away by all the crazy features built into this keyboard. I also didn't do my homework but now realize this is a bluetooth compatible board which is awesome as well. Admittedly I'm not a keyboard connoisseur and I haven't had this but an hour, so this is more of a first impressions review. Overall the typing experience feels petty similar to other mechanical keyboards I've used in the past with a few exceptions: They keytops have a sort of "rubber" feel to them which is very different from my PBT double shot Leopold keyboard. It almost feels like I have something sticky on my fingers which I imagine would take some getting used to. For example, if I'm sliding my fingers on from the "E" to the "D" there is some added resistance (this is probably bad typing form but it works for me). The case is indeed very high as some other reviewers have pointed out, and though I don't usually use a wrist pad it does feel more natural to have one with this keyboard. I'm using the "red" switch board and it feels pretty good. It's definitely not super quiet like my mx cherry silent Leopold but it's also not nearly as clicky as the blue or buckling springs I've used in the past. I think this really comes down to personal preference. This keyboard has a TON of features built in and the mac native designed is very much appreciate, which grants this a 5-star rating. Check out the video review attached to see the keyboard in action and the awesome lighting programs. For what it's worth I'm mostly typing "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog" over and over, or just mashing the keys to show off the light functions.

author: Amazon Customer

title: Great mechanical keyboard for Mac use!!!
content: This is the perfect mechanical keyboard to use with MacOS.  I use it with my M1 Mac Mini and have had no problems.  I use it wired so it wakes the Mac faster, but from what i hear, the bluetooth functionality is really good too.  I can't say from experience. It has the Mac specific buttons on the Function Keys which i use all the time.  This is what made me go for this specific Keychron keyboard.  Some of the others don't have the mac specific keys. The RGB lights are nice but not necessary.  A nice gimmicky addition. The keys themselves are a nice two tone grey color that makes the keyboard sleek and minimalistic.  Nothing gaudy except the orange escape key which i quite like for it's quirky look.  The aluminum base makes the keyboard feel super solid and high quality.  No flex at all.  Some people say that the keyboard sits too high to be ergonomically  comfortable but i have no problems at all.  You can always purchase a wrist rest if needed. The packaging is top notch and lets you know that you purchased a high quality product.  The keyboard comes with an included plastic dust cover, but i don't use it.  It's nice to have if you don't use the keyboard for long periods. Great value for the money!!!  I'm definitely a Keychron fan and so glad that my first Mechanical keyboard is the K2!

author: KeziaPurrs

title: Great "real" bluetooth keyboard (and great wired too)
content: Most bluetooth keyboards are cramped, very small layout, missing keys, and don't use keyswitches. Not this one, this is the real deal. Picked up the "brown" switch one, can't tell the difference from my real Cherry Brown keyboard. The full-sized layout means I don't have cramped fingers, the extra F keys and navigation keys are nice to have as well. The RGB lighting is nice to have, good diversity in patterns, though it's going to drain the battery much faster. I like that I can pair it with 3 devices and swap between them. The media and function keys work fine on MacOS and iOS. Keycaps have a simple, legible font, with the lighting shining through. The red ESC key lights up a bit bright and can be swapped out with the included grey version. Key travel is smooth with the browns, a little clacky bottoming out, I'll probably put some silicone o-rings on mine. Overall, this is a good keyboard for the price paid, it's comfortable to use and works great with Apple devices, at a cost far less than other hard-wired mechanical keyboards I've purchased (bit of a keyboard junkie here). It will take up more space in a backpack and you should get a padded sleeve for it  for protection. I can definitely recommend keyboard if you're looking for something a bit more than the typical portable bluetooth keyboard.

title: Fantastic keys and build quality, but very tall keys
content: The build quality is fantastic, the keys are impressively responsive and so pretty to look at. Great lighting modes with a very intuitive programing process. author: Kevin

title: Overall great, couple of glaring issues
content: I work in tech support and play PC games so even though this is my first mechanical keyboard I find myself using a wide variety of keyboards on a daily basis. This is my initial impression of the KeyChron K2 RGB with gateron brown switches. I am a PC user so i cant speak to its functionality on mac os. Pros: 1 1. The main reason I purchased this keyboard is that I needed a wired/wireless keyboard. I needed the freedom to connect to any device with my keyboard. Even in my own room i have a chromebit hooked up to my TV for streaming and such, my Desktop computer and my laptop. This does let me switch connections between all 3 with bluetooth without having to resync the keyboard. For gaming I needed the wired capabilities for quick response times and the overall trustworthiness of a wired connection. 2. I love the layout. I had an extremely hard time finding a keyboard with all the function keys, dedicated arrow keys, and lacked the number pad. It matches the vortex keyboard layout for $40 less. It makes it feel compact without loosing any functionality. 3. The clickety clack. Feels nice. Has an ASMR quality to it at night. When I brought it to work I felt a little self conscious about how loud it sounded even though the browns were supposed to be quiet. I asked my coworkers and they haven't noticed or are too polite to say anything. 4. Plug and play. No setup needed. Bluetooth was easy to connect as well. 5. RGB, plenty of options and it lets you cycle through specific solid colors for many of the patterns. Even though it its not fully programmable it does give plenty of options to play with. 6. Feels solid and high quality. 7. It has the largest battery at 4000mah. I do primarily use it in wired mode so I can't comment on how many hours this actually gives you. Cons: 1. For a $100 keyboard i would like some ability to customize the keys if i want to change layouts or program in macros. This keyboard does not support that by default. Keychron does not provide any software to edit the keyboard. Many cheaper wired RGB mechanical keyboards in the $40 range support this. I dont know why KeyChron didn't put feature this in. 2. Its tall. It stands at 1.5 inches and you will need a wrist pad to use this keyboard. At the same time most mechanical keyboards have a tall profile so this isn't directly attacking the KeyChron but it is something I wish I knew before purchasing it. You average non mechanical keyboard is probably only an inch tall with the feet up and that is at the back of it. 3. A lot keyboard lovers have complained about the keys registering a press before you actually hear the click. When I tested this myself it is true. It will send the command before you feel the actuation but its such a tiny portion of the key press that I don't know how anyone casually noticed this. It took me a few tries of careful key pressing before I was able to confirm this issue. This is probably a deal breaker for longtime mechanical keyboard users but the average person won't even notice this. 4. Not sure if this is an issue with all mechanical keyboards, just mine, or keychron, but the space bar doesn't have the same feel or sound as the rest of the keys. It was one of the first things i noticed when using it. TLDR: Tall profile, and no software support really hold this keyboard back for what it costs. I considered returning it because of Cons #1 and #2 but I cant find one with this same layout that is dual wired/wireless.

title: Not the best compact mechanical, but EASILY the best value for your money (and it's wireless!)
content: Let's get the objective stuff out of the way first: the keyboard has really solid build quality on the surface. Heck, there aren't too many keyboards that satisfy 3 of the 5 qualities. The Keychron feels like a premium product, for less than you'd think, and comes with some really neat accessories (Mac and windows key caps, an angled USB-C wire, and perhaps the most unique and functional keycap remover I've ever seen...good job guys!) title: A good keyboard overall with one big defect
content: This is my second Keychron K2. I had the original version with the plastic frame and blue switches, but decided to get the aluminium frame with red switches (blue is too clicky for me). I have enjoyed the typing experience on both of mine and for the price they're hard to beat when considering the features. While I had no issues with my first K2, the current one has not been perfect. From the get-go, both the power switch and Mac/Windows switch were very difficult to move. At times they would slide perfectly, but most of the time I really had to dig into the switch to get it to move. Fast forward about 6 months, and the power switch stopped functioning entirely. I disassembled the keyboard to find the switch had in fact broken internally. While I could still move the switch outside, it was no longer attached to the circuitboard inside and thus did nothing. The circuitboard switch inside was very tiny and I can understand why it broke so soon. Unfortunately, this left the keyboard stuck on wired mode and I am currently unable to turn it off or switch to Bluetooth mode (which was a feature that first attracted me to this keyboard in the first place). Something changed in the switch design from V1 to V2, as my original K2's power switch moved perfectly with little resistance and very nice "clicks". Having searched around online, I see I'm not alone in this issue and I've read other reports of power switches no longer working. Overall, I am disappointed my still shiny and fairly new K2 has already lost a lot of functionality after only 6 months. I really enjoy typing on my K2, but given I now have a $100 wired-only keyboard, I will probably look to other brands for a replacement since I need the Bluetooth functionality. I am giving this 2 stars as it's a great keyboard when it works as intended.

title: Quality keyboard, exactly what I needed
content: tldr; quality keyboard that satisfied my needs, especially for keyboard layout. Would recommend. I am a student who uses my laptop frequently for gaming, programming, etc. I was looking for a mechanical keyboard with several key conditions: 1. Wireless - I haven't had any issues with this keyboard's bluetooth, it connects quickly when I turn it on and hasn't had any hiccups. I purchased a pouch to carry the keyboard around with me. 2. Key layout - I cannot stress how rare it is for a compact keyboard to have this layout. There are some keys I cannot live without in certain positions, e.g. tilde in top left, delete, designated arrow keys (!), home/end, and a semi-large right shift key. I use both shifts when I type so I was deterred by all of the compact keyboards with just a regular single-sized key as the right shift button. This one I believe is 1.5 (not sure) and though it's definitely not the same full size as left shift, it is large enough. Also I do find myself using the function row quite frequently as well. The keyboard layout feels similar to my laptop layout, so there was an easy adjustment. 3. Brown switches - This is my first mechanical keyboard so I am not sure how the switches compare. However I've heard that brown switches are best for maintaining a balance between a tactile (there is a slight bump before the key goes down) and quiet (honestly still pretty loud but it sounds nice). 4. RGB - lights are cool, they give plenty of options for lighting patterns and switching colors. I don't think there is a software for custom mapping but given their options I didn't feel like it was lacking. The lights are not too bright but they can easily be seen in dim lighting and they shine through the keycap lettering so the letters change color as well. The build quality feels sturdy for me (aluminum frame). I heard mixed opinions about the keycaps but there other keycap options out there if anybody feels the need to replace them (I'm not sure how the stock ones compare). The only thing I had an issue with at first is the keyboard has a power-saving feature where it autosleeps, but then it seems like it goes through the entire reconnect process again when it wakes up, which causes a slight delay. Minor inconvenience, but the user manual includes the shortcut for disabling autosleep. The battery has been enough to last a couple days for me on each charge with full RGB running at all times even without the autosleep. I recommend charging overnight if you plan to use wirelessly.

author: Josh Frechem

title: Solid Mac-first keyboard, with only a few caveats...
content: Since I needed new peripherals to go along with my new M1 Mac mini last November, after years of typing on flat MacBooks, I decided to finally treat myself to my first mechanical keyboard since the original IBM PC was offered with one.  After a long online dive, when I surfaced I had decided on the 75% Keychron Wireless Backlit RGB with Brown switches and Aluminum Frame. For me, these Browns by Gateron are an acceptable compromise between mechanical feel and reasonable noise, just as long as you are okay with the lack any actual mechanical "break" when actuating. I prefer not waking up the house late at night!  That being said, I do sometimes still miss a clearly felt mechanical actuation feel, but this works for me, and is still legions ahead of any membrane keyboard, or Apple's own.  I The keyboard is rather tall, but not exceptionally so.  I use it with the rear feet extended for a more sloped typing angle, which helps.  I ordered the matching Keychron Wooden Palm Rest in anticipation of this and it makes a big difference when I do serious typing.  I also prefer the feel of the finished wood on my palms over spongy fabric covered palmrests, or the bare glass top of my desk. When just casually surfing the web or doing other non-typing-intensive tasks, I put away the palmrest since it just tends to get in the way if I have to move the keyboard around and have desk clutter. Bluetooth is rock-solid, with never a glitch or delay, ever.  In fact the connection is far more reliable than with Apple's Magic Trackpad 2 that I bought at the same time.  If I recall, I think I had to use a wired connection just once, to be able to boot up my brand new M1 Mac mini.  This is a condition specific to only the M1 versions when using a non-Apple keyboard on a new machine. The RGB color options and patterns, though entertaining as heck at first, end up becoming more of a distraction after a while.  I ended up using one preferred color pretty much all the time. Keyboard circus lights can be distracting! A note on the colors, specifically blue.  Normally a color I might choose, this blue is not very bright, even when turned all the way up in the dark.  I always end up using the brightest setting for all the colors, all the time, to get to a decent brightness level.  Except for blue.  I find it far too subtle.  in my photos I use cyan/teal, which I like very much. Battery life with the RGB lighting activated is an issue, but it's addressed in the descriptions when you buy it.  Expect to get a full day's use out of it, then plug it in overnight so you're ready to go in the morning.  With the illumination turned off, it's much longer, maybe a few days. After nearly a year of use, I can say I am still satisfied with my purchase.  I wish the lighting was a tad brighter, and the rubber on one of the folding feet has disappeared (a much bigger problem on the Keychron Palm Rest on which ALL of the pads slid right off it's base - a BIG problem since it'll wobble without!), but not enough suffer any buyers remorse.  The keycaps still look good with crisp lettering, and they haven't acquired significant shine from use yet.  Battery life is as purchased.  it still looks and types great.  Whether or not you consider it's reasonable cost vs. comparably featured keyboards from some others, it's a worthy purchase. Except for that one rubber foot-pad... When one falls off, you know more will eventually follow.  Especially when you consider how awful they were on my Palmrest.  I tried everything to get them to stick - unacceptable that they all fell off within a few weeks of purchase. Keychron, you make some good gear that I'm comfortable recommending to others.  I want mine made right again; how does one get replacement feet, please?

title: Extremely satisfied with this keyboard
content: Full disclosure: the first keyboard I received was defective, but the Amazon return/replace procedure is incredibly simple and helpful—I had a replacement delivered to my door in less than 24 hours. Second disclosure: this is my first entry into the world of mechanical keyboards, so I am not able to compare and contrast well between other models and other features. I can simply describe my satisfaction with this keyboard. I am incredibly happy with this keyboard: I didn't know I was missing this. The keyboard itself is heavier than I thought it would be—though I think that I actually really appreciate this since it makes the unit very sturdy. One of the negative reviews I have seen has to do with the height of the board: I tend to type with floating wrists, so it doesn't bother me at all, but I can imagine that someone who rests their wrists while they work might be uncomfortable and might require some sort of additional rest. The battery life seems to last very long (I charge it infrequently, and it has yet to show a low battery indication). I like the various RGB light settings, though I usually keep it on a static white setting without effect. I opted for the 'blue' switches, which are in fact quite noisy, but I love them. The switches are responsive but also firm: you always know when you have activated the key press and, in my case, I can notice my 'errors' based on whether or not the click was felt. One of the reviewers brought up typing accuracy: this keyboard in no way interferes with any accuracy—I suspect that the reviewer simply does not know how to type properly and is utterly reliant on spell check. It is true that this is a very different feel from, for example, a standard Apple magic keyboard or MacBook Air etc.; but for anyone who grew up typing on early word processors and 90s desktop computers, this keyboard might actually activate a sort of nostalgia. Again, the blue switches are very noisy: probably not recommended for a shared workspace. I am now interested to learn more about the differences between linear, tactile, and clicky switches, however for now am very satisfied with my clicky gateron blues. The price point (I did get these on a sale) seemed right to me. Overall, then, this seems to be a very good introduction to a wireless mechanical keyboard. Happy clicking.

author: B Garcia

title: Solid mechanical keyboard replacement for Apple Magic Keyboard
content: The Keychron K2 provides a solid bluetooth/wireless keyboard alternative to the Apple Magic Keyboard, particularly if Apple's Magic Keyboard doesn't provide enough key travel and as a result recognizes key pressure too readily.  The Keychron K2 keycaps are spaced more widely apart allowing for less typing errors created from accidentally pressing 2 adjacent keys at once.  In addition, the Keychron K2 provides back lighting (albeit in a myriad of 15+ lighting options all of which I will probably never take advantage). Having stated that, because the Keychron K2 is a 3rd party accessory, it is not as conveniently integrated with macOS as is a native Apple keyboard: 1. The Keychron K2 will not allow one to login to macOS wirelessly over bluetooth upon powering on or rebooting your Mac if you have File Vault disk encryption enabled.  This is not the fault of Keychron as currently Apple does not load 3rd party keyboard drivers prior to login in order to maintain the security of the encrypted Mac.  (While Keychron developers are open to resolving this issue, I'm not sure how much if anything they can do without Apple's assistance.). The K2 can be used to login if the included USB-C cable is used to connect the keyboard to the Mac. 2. While the K2 for Mac is designed for Mac compatibility and includes the Command, Mission Control and Search keys, etc. it does not include an Eject key.  So if one is accustomed to using the Control+Option+Eject keyboard combination to Restart your Mac, for example, then a 3rd party app, Karabiner, is required to program a keyboard shortcut to emulate the Eject key (i.e. Control+fn+escape). In addition, the Keychron K2 has a taller profile than the Apple Magic Keyboard so for true typists a wrist rest is probably necessary.  Finally, while Keychron states the sound level for the Gateron Brown Switch based keyboard is Gentle, as might be expected it is noticeably louder than the Apple Magic Keyboard.

I got some advice from the younger generation and bought this so-called gaming keyboard. Never used it for gaming, but never regretted getting it. If you do anything serious on the computer, it is essential to have a well-made keyboard that is designed for heavy use every day. Cost doesn't matter that much compared to day after day of frustration fighting the chiclets. I feel as though I rolled the dice and came up with a big win.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020
author: Michael G. Shafto

title: some keys have a "sticky" feeling to them
content: So my first issue is that the first keyboard I got didn't charge. The only way it worked was to have it connected to usb, which defeats the purpose of this keyboard. After I got a replacement, the keyboard charges and I can use it wirelessly now. However both keyboards had the same problem: several of the keys have a sticky response to them. the left shift and spacebar on the second keyboard has a sticky feeling to it, which really throws me off since it feels like I didnt press it. Unfortunately, I can't seem to find another keyboard that offers the features this one does, so I think I'm stuck with this keyboard. Minor peeve: led lightshow is cool and all, but i really couldnt care less for all the unnecessary light shows. A simple white backlight is good enough...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
author: Amazon Customer

title: Great keyboard, battery life could be better
content: I guess I was spoiled a bit by my Apple wireless keyboard, which lasted for what felt like months in between charges. This is more like a weekly thing. Not bad, but a bit inconvenient given that I use it in the living room and have to carry it to the charger (where it can't be used at the same time). The rest of the keyboard is great. Relatively inexpensive, easy to set up, compact, reliably connected, feels great to type on. The LEDs work just fine but it's not really my cuppa to leave them on. Edit: having looked at some of the other reviews, I do want to point out my own experience with bluetooth lag: I haven't noticed any substantial (or even noticeable) lag whatsoever. I haven't once had to wait for the keyboard to catch up, and I've been playing Doom Eternal without any issue. And I've had no problems maintaining a reliable connection. I also don't notice the keyboard go to sleep (though my other keychron keyboard, a k6 that I use for work, does go to sleep after a moment ... which is annoying).

author: James Cunningham

title: I love it!
content: I love it! Not only was it exactly as advertised, but it was absurdly easy to set up. With the provided instructions, which were nearly unnecessary due to the intuitive design, I was up and running on an essay I’m writing for a class in under five minutes from the first cut into the packaging. A day into use, I’m more in love with it than I was on arrival. The ergonomics are relatively good (love the two-option wee feet on the back in addition to the lay-flat option). The size is perfect. The color options are super fun and easy to play around with. And the operation of the blue option switches is a delight. I love the clickiness and travel. And all of this as a super reasonable price. I’m using this to replace another great, but way more expensive and physically large keyboard, the Logitech Pro. Can’t recommend more highly.

author: C. Stuart

title: Great keyboard, with bad glitches
content: This keyboard is awesome in almost every way and I love it, while it works.  When using it on my PC via bluetooth, everything will work fine for a while, but then suddenly the keyboard will decide it wants to just hold down whatever keys I press for as long as it wants.  This resulted in me hitting 'backspace' and accidentally deleting multiple rows of text I did not intend to delete, all while desperately trying to hit buttons on the keyboard and click away to prevent the deletion.  So, basically the keyboard is worthless to anyone who is actually serious about typing, unless they can release a new version where this sitting-on-the-keys thing is fixed. Really sad that such an awesome keyboard is so unreliable.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
author: Curbe

title: A Pretty Great Keyboard
content: After using the Apple Keyboard and mouse, I had been dealing with some terrible wrist and hand pain. I wanted a solution to help better my typing posture and was recommended this keyboard. Once I got it, I was so surprised by all its features. I love the connectivity and overall typing experience. It is something I have to adjust to, but in a matter of days it's gotten easier and the pain I'd dealt with is pretty much nonexistent. Other features I like are the colorful RGB lighting, the fact I have three different angles to choose from in terms of the incline, and the fact I and switch from typing on my computer to typing on my iPad. That does lead to my one con though... When it came to figuring out how to switch devices, it was a bit confusing. Reading the pamphlet that came in the box, it was a little bit vague??? I mean I am more of a visual learner, so even when I looked for "How To" videos, it didn't help either. Most of them were review or cool ad videos that didn't display how to connect, disconnect and then switch to a different device. After an hour or two of messing around, I finally figured out (what I think is the right way) to switch from one device to the other. So if anyone reading the reviews is having an issue with that let me know and I can share what I do to switch. Other than that I like this keyboard from the sound/switches I chose (brown), RGB lighting, and overall typing experience. I would for sure recommend this to anyone who wants a MAC/WINDOWS friendly mechanical keyboard.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2021
author: Monserratt V.

title: Pésima conexión Bluetooth, no lo recomendaría.

author: Hojjat

title: Awesome for Mac & Windows
content: I use this mechanical keyboard for my Mac and Lenovo as switching back and forth from Apple OS to Windows is a breeze. I’ve had it for over a month now and simply love it. Very satisfying key feedback. It has renewed my desire to type away content I’ve been putting off simply due to it stellar form. One thing to note - it does make a noise and is fairly loud. On ZOOM calls, typing does get noticed by colleagues. However, that hasn’t been the dealbreaker. The lighting is cool, and so is it’s small footprint. Hands down, the best keyboard I’ve ever had.

author: Royaldane

title: Beautiful piece of kit and a great, affordable intro to the universe of mechanical keyboards.
content: NOTE: Depending on which previous keyboard style you're coming from (Apple Magic Keyboard in my case), there will be a period of time where you will need to adjust and get comfortable to get back up to your original touch-typing speed without errors. This isn't specific to this particular product, just an aside that it is taking a bit for my muscle memory to adapt. I definitely recommend a wrist rest, as the keyboard does sit quite a bit higher than I'm used to. Your milage may vary, but it really helped in my case. I went with the aluminum frame/RGB version. Fit and finish on the aluminum bumpers is super clean. It really adds some heft and ups the quality of the feel. It's still relatively portable, but the extra weight keeps it put where you set it. I didn't think the RGB backlighting would matter much to me, because I'm using it in my design studio and the rainbow-chase effects don't appeal much to me. But what's really nice is that there is a static lighting setting and you can change the color of the RGB backlight to any of those RGB colors. The images I had seen online only showed static white, but the RGB version lets you pick. The Mac-centric media keys are a rarity in third-party offerings and are appreciated here. I ended up with the Gateron Brown switches and I think they're perfect for my personal preference, but you'll need to make your own way down that crazy rabbit hole to make your decision. Overall, really great look and functionality. It's also convenient to have the hotkeys to switch between my Macs/iOS devices on the fly. I was a little concerned at first because I couldn't find a caps lock status light, but it turns out that once it's engaged, the actual caps lock key's shine-through color becomes red. It's the little touches like this that has impressed me with this keyboard.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
author: Ryan

title: Suprising
content: It's like when you go to a restaurant, and you know their specials are good but you look up and down the menu and you see something that sounds just good enough to try so you order it and it's perfectly cooked, gorgeously plated, and perfectly proportioned. It surprises all 5 of your senses and awakens a 6th you didn't even know you had. That's this keyboard. It tickles the line between conscious and unconscious. The lucidness of dreams, and the inexplicable desire for control over them. With matter crashing in on itself; folding like origami. Recongizible faces you simply can't place and names you can't find faces for. Yet, despite the struggle for humanity within yourself, you find satisfaction. Peace. It's a beautiful salmon bisque, topped with roasted veggies and lathered in the most ecstasy-inducing sauce your momma would be proud of. It's a good keyboard, it'll do.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2021
author: Anders

title: Couple things I wish it has.
content: I like the keyboard a lot! Battery last a reasonable amount of time. It has a sleep function on by default to save battery when not in used. For me, I typed faster and more accurate with this over my G710+. Things I wish it has: 1) A brighter RGB backlights,  2)RF connection with USB dongle for faster connection, 3)USB passthrough for wired connection, 4) software support for RGB syncing/customization, 5) Volume scroller (I missed it from G710+)

author: Amazon Customer

title: All my worries are gone. It's an amazing Keyboard!
content: had a few worries because some Youtuber said it's shit. After the first test typing, I realize that it's the Youtuber who's full of shit. This is an amazing keyboard. 1. The K2 looks a bit fat with the aluminum housing in some pictures, but in actuallity, it's very sleek and compact. 2. Some find the Gateron Red Switches a bit meek compared to Cherry Reds. I am a all time Cherry Red user myself, and this is my first time trying these switches. Honestly, it feels great. It's pleasantly light and yet has a satisfying accoustics when the switches hit the bottom and then the top. It's not a silent switch, but it's not annoyingly loud like some blue switches. The factory lubrication is perfect and I couldn't have done it better myself. It could be used in some office settings where it's not too quiet. 3. It had one defect though. One key (i.e. the Y-key in the picture) had a little bump that was very noticeable when typing. I was going to change to custom keycaps anyway, but it's not some thing that you would expect in a over $100 keyboard. For the time being, I had to remove the bump with a sandfile but visually, it is damaged now. Overall, even with the defect, I am completely satisfied. I was looking for a  keyboard with very specific specs: 75% 84-key layout, Bluetooth 5.0 or better, alluminum housing, and, preferably, hot-swappable PCB. The last requirement had to go because hotswappable models are out of stock everywhere, but with these amazing switches, I don't think I need it anymore. Keychron keyboards are amazing and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

author: Korean Keyboard Enthusiast

title: Red switches turned out too loud but good compromise for Mac
content: I got the Gateron Red Switch v2 which I thought would be the quietest, but the typing is very loud. I cannot conduct phone meetings so will be getting a new keyboard. I do enjoy the different light options although, in my opinion, they do not necessarily look good against the grey keys. The lights are fun though. At first I was concerned the height of the keyboard would be too high. After 6 months of use, I have gotten used to the height without getting a wrist rest. However, even after 6 months, I have not gotten used to the keybindings since it is a mini keyboard. I am constantly hitting print screen instead of delete. I also used the Bluetooth connection at first but switched to using the USB connection since it is much more reliable. I do enjoy that it is compatible with Mac and Windows. I am constantly switching between the two. This seems to be one of the few mechanical keyboards for Mac out there. I think I will try this same keyboard with quieter switches and switching my keybindings.

title: I really did want to like this keyboard
content: i wanted to get something for my mac other than the typical chiclet keyboards and since I also game on PC, I'm used to using a mechanical keyboard. I really did want to like this keyboard. People complained about the height of the keyboard but since I have bigger hands I decided to just order a wrist rest along with it. The keys actually feel nice and aren't slippery like your default plastic keys (think Razer keyboards if you're familiar). The aluminum case feels hefty and solid. The reason I gave it one star is because the bluetooth is consistently disconnecting from my computer so I have to constantly reconnect it. The reconnection isn't easy either. Often times, I have to factory reset the keyboard or turn it off and back on then reconnect the bluetooth. It's a nightmare. The one thing I bought it for and it can't do it. There's also been times when the buttons are "stuck" and will hold the key I just pressed. It really is unfortunate cause the keyboard feels great, at least to me. It does come with a usb c to usb a cable so if you want a wired connection then this might work out for you. Look, if you're looking for a wireless keyboard, this ain't it chief. I really do wish it was but with all the connectivity issues, it just isn't worth it.

content: I recently purchased a mechanical keyboard for my PC and decided I needed one for my Mac as well - the Mathias keyboard just didn't feel good to type on anymore.
