title: A perfect wireless mechanical keyboard for $100
content: $100 is a lot to spend on a keyboard. This is the best keyboard you can buy for the money though. It's compact yet spacious, it has an amazing feel to it, and the build quality is superb. I haven't used a mechanical keyboard in a long time, but this is one of the best I've used. The keys are clicky (I'm a big fan of hearing the click) and it types wonderfully. The backlighting feature is great, with multiple settings for color and brightness, and has different mode for different OS (Windows/And and Mac/iOS). I have the aluminim version, and it is built amazingly. It's hefty and durable. The only somewhat negative thing about this keyboard is its height. It's a bit tall, but once you get used to it, it's fine. You can also buy a small wrist rest if you so desire. For gaming, it's okay, not great. content: This is my first mechanical keyboard. title: Astounding keyboard - highly recommended!

title: Mostly an improvement on the K1
content: I backed this keyboard on kickstarter, and I bought the K1 while waiting to get this keyboard. The K1 had a serious issue with input sensitivity. You could barely tap a key and a keypress would register. Also, when using the keyboard with bluetooth it would frequently have issues where it would just randomly send long strings of characters. The K2 has none of this. I received the RGB metal Red switch model, and I love it. The key switches are an improvement over the K1. However, there are a few things that I don't like about the keyboard: 1. While the 84 key layout is fashionable I find it inferior to the K1's layout, especially the exclusion of a print screen key in favor of a screen capture key that has different mappings based upon which OS you have it set to. 2. On the K1 the switches and plug for the cable were on the back. On the K2 it is on the left side which is a bad idea. I am not left handed, but those who are and prefer using their mouse with their left hand shouldn't use this keyboard. 3. The K1's caps lock would light up when toggled on. The K2 gives no indication that the caps lock is on which is annoying. 4. I picked the RGB model because I wanted the aluminum chassis, but I wish there were an aluminum model with white LEDs. I'd prefer to have the LEDs off than have them be RGB. 5. I find myself hitting the LED mode key on the top right instead of the delete key far more often than I should which causes me to then have to press it a ridiculous amount of times to get back to my preferred LED setting. In a future model that key should be removed from the keyboard and instead be a toggle switch on the back of the keyboard. Once I set the LEDs like I like them there's no need to ever press that key again. 6. The end user should be able to customize the firmware of the keyboard with custom key settings. Remapping them in software isn't possible when for instance the screen grab key sends multiple keystrokes. I could also perhaps disable the LED light key as well. This would mostly solve two issues I have with the keyboard alone.

title: Fantastic produce.... except... left shift key seems to "break" easily
content: Ugh, wrote a long review and Amazon "lost" it. But I feel strongly about this so I'll try and write it again. This is a keyboard I want to love. It uses cherry switches which provide the feedback you want when programming or just touch typing.  You can choose which cherry switch (red, brown, black) from the most common ones out there (if you're not familiar with cherry switches or the differences, you should google it before selecting which keyboard you want).  Its only a slightly bigger footprint than the Apple wireless keyboard but is much taller (to accommodate the keys).  With the feet to tilt it and the long life battery, I would normally say this is a winner of a keyboard... and was about to write a review to that effect when... after two weeks... The left SHIFT key stopped working correctly.  Now since the shift key (like the return, space, or any larger than normal key) uses a mechanism to insure that the entire key goes up and down in a straight motion, I was suprised that with less than two weeks of use, that mechanism broke on the shift key.  What ends up happening of course is when you press the shift key, it doesn't come back up.  The second picture shows how it "jams" at an angle and requires either several taps or a paperclip to get back up.  Of course with programming or just about any typing, this effectively makes the keyboard a throw away.  I'm returning mine to "hopefully" get a replacement that last longer.  I'll add to this review if it has the same failure. I was very happy with the keyboard up until that point. At this point, its a paper weight in my laptop bag as I take it to the UPS store for return.  I do wish there was a better indication of battery life remaining as I've had it run out of power on me a few times without understanding that it was low.

author: Marcos D.

title: The world of Mac capable keyboards is bleak.
content: In a world of PC dominated mechanical keyboard options, the keychron k2 has stepped up. I am very impressed with the design and the options available for this keyboard. It is really sleek with the aluminum frame and I love the integration within Mac specific keys. I have multiple other mechanical keyboards that I use and when it comes to using them on any of my Mac interfaces, nothing compares to the keychron. With other boards I would have to either re write commands in gmk or just accept that I would have very limited capabilities when using them with Mac OS. But not with the K2. All my Mac specific commands worked right out of the box with the K2. And the multiple Bluetooth profiles are a blessing too. I can move my board from my iMac to my iPad to my iPhone all with two key strokes. The only thing I wish was an option was different colors with the board. A white version or an all black version would be great. The aluminum base is great and I know you can change keycaps ( which I have ) but having base color options would be a great addition. Also the location of the usb-c not ideal for me. I feel like it really looses aesthetic on my desk set up when I have it plugged in. The connection should definitely come out the back and not out of the side. But that’s all personal preference of course. But despite that it really is the only keyboard on the market that can fully integrate with Mac OS out of the box. I highly recommend this board.

title: Great Value on a Great Keyboard

Feel, solid, especially with the metal frame, but I also added o-rings to my keycaps when I replaced them. Mac compatible, not a thing for me, but I know for a lot of people this is a BIG deal. Works wirelessly or wired. Negatives. Feel. Solid enough, but I'd still add some O-rings just to make everything feel rock solid. They are still working on some firmware issues. I think for macs, you still need to update the firmware from a windows machine, though they MAY have fixed this issue. If its a problem for you, verify before you buy. Some nonstandard key placement due to the reduced footprint layout. This may be an issue for some touch typists. (I know for me, the bracket and quote keys sometime give me a problem, but I still LOVE it). Over all? You simply can't go wrong for the money for the value here. I bought mine with the brown gateron switches and this is, simply a great feeling keyboard.

title: Wait for the Keychron K8, coming July 2020
content: I just wrote a long review and it got erased so I'm going to sum it up quickly. The Keychron is a great Mac-native-layout keyboard. I got a wrist rest to help solve the problem, but I bought a memory foam wrist rest and it's not good, so I'm returning it for a stiffer one. The main annoying thing is the layout of the keys. There are page up, page down, home and end keys on the right side that you easily accidentally hit and lose your place in a doc you're working on. Which brings me to the K8. title: Fantastic value
content: I had a simple set of needs, Bluetooth, TKL, and tactile/quiet switches, with Mac keycaps being a welcome extra. I have the Apple Magic Keyboard, but frankly, the typing experience is somewhat subpar. It's also the one with numeric input, so I was struggling with portability. This popped up in my search, and I decided to jump on the wagon. I'm not sure I would use it for gaming or anything that requires my hands to stay in place for a long period of time, the height is pretty insane compared to my dedicated gaming keyboard (Corsair K95), but I wanted something more portable, and this thing hits every mark I was looking for. The keyboard feels very well made. Very little deck flex. Switches between devices in a couple seconds seamlessly. I'm actually a little shocked at how well it switches between devices. I read some reviews about mistyping, and I was a little concerned, but now that I received it, I can solidly say the only mistakes are the ones I make, but with a caveat. The key spacing is a bit wider than most other keyboards I've used, and that has caused a slight uptick in my typing mistakes. It's only fractions of a millimeter larger between keys, but by the end of the keyboard, those slight additions add up to a couple millimeters. If you're jumping between keyboard regularly, that could get annoying, but I'm really only using my other keyboard for gaming, so my left hand doesn't notice the difference, and I anticipate once I'm a little more used to this keyboard, i'll no longer have any issues. Now the hunt begins for a wrist rest I'll actually like...

title: Awesome mechanical keyboard for Apple devices
content: I just read today that this keyboard made it to Engadgets Top 5 list for 2020. Having used this one myself for work on my Macbooks, I can attest that this keyboard is very worthy of that honor. There aren't a lot of Mac-specific mechanical keyboards out there, most are tailored for PCs with many Mac users opting for the keyboards made by Apple. Those are fine, but there are many that still prefer the robustness and durability that mechanical keyboards come with. This one is made with Macs in mind, including all the shortcut keys, which is a tremendous help. I love the design of the keyboard. Solid construction, beautiful keys, and the many backlight patterns are a nice touch. Typing on the keyboard feels great, very responsive. What also makes this keyboard stand out is the versatility. The keyboard can be used wirelessly via bluetooth or wired via USB with the flip of a switch. It's designed for Macs, but comes with replacement keys for PC users as well and will work with Windows/Linux computers as well with a flip of a switch. The bluetooth connectivity allows for up to 3 devices to be remembered. Meaning you can switch where your keyboard is connected to other devices easily using the fn+1, 2, or 3 keys that have the bluetooth icon on them. Meaning you can also connect this keyboard to mobile devices like an iPad (the keyboard is very handy for use with an iPad as well). All in all, this is a well designed, well built keyboard that's about as versatile as it gets and is ideal for Apple users who want a mechanical keyboard that meets their needs. Highly recommended.

title: clicky clacky fun
content: This is my initial review of my k2 v2 brown switch rgb keyboard. So far I am enjoying myself lol.  I never thought I'd have so much fun just typing, but hitting these keys makes typing away really fun.  This is my first mechanical keyboard (other than growing up on some old school apple ones), so I'm sorta trying to feel out what this whole mechanical keyboard thing is about. I chose the brown switches because I heard they were a good balance between tactile actuation and typing speed.  I was looking for something that would be both comfortable to use in the office and during gaming time.  Pretty satisfied with the typing feel of these browns.  I soooortaa wish they were a little more clicky.  Like that there was a slight snap right before the type registering.  The cherry browns might have that feeling, but I heard the gateron browns are less like that and offer less fatigue during typing marathons.  If I could describe this typing experience with the gateron browns it would be: swift-clicky and fast-smooth. The sound to the clicky typing is really enjoyable and lends to the physical experience of typing.  Pressing the space bar is a triumph.  It's also got a good sound.  The gateron blues sounded too high pitch for my liking in videos I've seen. Other reviews mention that the key caps seem a bit thin and it's weird that I can sense that too, but it doesn't bother me too much.  I will probably upgrade the caps in the future. Not sure why, but my UP arrow was replaced with another "control" keycap.  Not sure if someone messed up in assembly or that they just ran out of up arrows.  It wasn't provided in the collection of extra caps that came with the keyboard.  I'm not SO bothered by it because I'll probably replace the caps sometime in the future, and I guess it's a nice little reminder that a human being was on the other end assembling this thing. Surprised how well the RGB lighting enhances the keys.  The character areas of the keys are see through and the lights shines through the empty spaces of the keys.  I like colors, but find them a bit annoying if they don't serve any purpose (I have rgb shut off on my rig)  but these don't bother me too much and you can adjust the brightness.  Got a subdued rainbow thing going on now. Pairing the keyboard with bluetooth was a little confusing at first.  The manual mentions to "press 1+fn" to pair  but it actually means "HOLD 1+fn."  Your computer should recognize your device and your 1 key should blink blue waiting for you to pair through your computer. The aluminum case feels strong and the weight of the thing feels substantial. Not sure about the battery life yet, but I'll remember to talk about that in an updated review. I ended up getting a glorious gaming wrist rest (tenkeyless size) for this thing.  It seems to suit the keyboard well.  It's a bit larger than the keyboard, but I wanted the freedom to rest my wrists at weird angles.  Other reviewers have complained about how high this keyboard is.  I have messed up wrists and really don't  want to find out how uncomfortable this thing would be without wrist rests.  Can imagine a compact wooden wrist rest working well with this thing, but none were in stock at my time of purchase. Just learned that there is a hotswappable version of the K2 :(  I think I would have gotten that one if I had known about it, but I think I'm still pretty satisfied with this version.  There have been reviews complaining about the reliability of the hotswappable keychrons and the hotswappable K2 doesn't have enough reviews to qualify me confidently purchasing it. So far pretty satisfied with my purchase.  Not totally blown away ( I think I would need to build my own mechanical keyboard to get it perfect), but it's a nice and solid introduction to the material enjoyment of mechanical keyboards. Review update, one week of use: Getting pretty fond of this keyboard.  I don't know if it's me reading more about mechanical keyboards on reddit or if I'm really starting to be that picky, but these stock keycaps are annoying the pants off of me.  They have a high pitch tap, sound a bit hollow, and feel thin.  It's strange that those are things that you can register in your brain, but maybe having much better quality switches unlocked new senses in my noggin. I ended up ordering a set of new keycaps.  They are double shot pbt's with a cherry profile and I got them here on amazon.  Non-backlit because I kept reading bad sensory feedback on anything that was backlit or translucent (i.e.  shine throughs or translucent puddings).  Be sure to look for keycap sets for 84 keys or a 75% layout with a cherry mx compatibility.  Also, refer to the keycap layout and size map on keychron's website for a sizing comparison.  found it hard to find keycap sets for this 75% layout.  You either have to buy a set meant for a larger keycap layout or really find a special set.  You can find a 75% set on KBD fans, find a few here on amazon, be lucky to find a set on mass drop, or order a custom one for 75% keyboards on wasdkeyboards.com (*note that they can only make it out of ABS plastic).  Another option is to buy a set meant for a smaller layout and live with having the stock keycaps on for your rightside alt, fn, control, and shift keys. It would be icing on my sensory cake to have special switches for things ( like a clicky blue for the "esc" key, "enter", or "space bar" but so far really liking these browns.  I've read that the zealio purple switches have a similar feel, but more of a bump.  Probably be into a keyboard of those in the future.

title: One of the best wireless mechanical keyboard on the market!
content: Found out about this keyboard from Instagram, and backed the original kickstarter on a whim. I was in the market for a wireless keyboard, and most of the reputable ones were either low-quality ones for using with a TV or obnoxious gaming models like the G613. The Anne Pro 2 and Drevo Calibur were often recommended, but their form-factors and key selection were too small for my needs. The Keychron K2 is in a sweet spot for me because it's mechanical, has a simple aesthetic suitable for both office/gaming, and has enough keys for me to be productive while still keeping the footprint small: PROS: - Mechanical + wireless, a pretty rare breed in the market right now - Bluetooth connection, no dongles - USB-C port, you don't have to keep a micro-sd around just for this device - Mac + Windows modes + extra keycaps. Most mechs do not support Macs at all. - Battery life is good if you use the default power-saving mode (sleeps after 10 mins) CONS: - Bluetooth connection from sleep can be a bit spotty. Sometimes it will connect in 2 seconds, sometimes it'll take 8-10. - Slight glitch where the keyboard will type in CAPS for the first 1-2 letters as it wakes up - Chassis is thicker than most keyboards throughout the body, so this keyboard can start to hurt if you're not using a palmrest. - Gateron switches aren't that great. It definitely keeps the cost low, but I find that these gaterons are less smooth, specifically comparing the Gateron browns in my unit to the Cherry MX Browns in my CoolerMaster QuickFire Rapid. - Non-standard TKL layout. Since the layout isn't really found in any other keyboards, your muscle memory won't transfer as well, especially if you use multiple keyboards. Overall, a great keyboard for people who want to declutter their desk but still enjoy the feeling of a mechanical. Keys feel fine (not amazing), and the wireless mode is fine for casual gaming. Wired mode is just as reliable as a normal wired keyboard, with better response time.

content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. First off, I would like to mention that mine is the 1st version k2. But the changes between the first and second version isn’t much. But I guess everyone has there own opinion. I am sure that anyone, especially teenagers, would immediately chose the blue switches as they sound the most satisfying. But I think everyone grows out of this stage. For me, I left my keychron k2 in my drawer because of how much I disliked the blue switches and inability to use them in the night. When I wanted to mod my k2 I emailed customer support many times to ask for specifications and etc, and I would get immediate responses. Usually less than a day. What I did to my keychron k2: Neoprene foam (1/8”) between plate and pcb 3 layers of 1/8” neoprene foam in the case. O-ring mounted and only used 4 standoffs to screw in to the case Bandaid modded stabs by putting bandaids on both the plate and pcb, and I also hole bandaid modded the stabs (but I don’t recommend hole bandaid mod since it results in mushy sounding). Replaced stock stabs with everglide clipin stabs lubed with krytox 205g0 Lubed and filmed novelkey creams. SA PBT Keycaps Spray painted case gloss white. Used self etching primer, gloss white enamel, and gloss clear enamel (please don’t spray paint, use a brush instead). I ran through 6 cans of spray paint so far, messed up multiple times, and still left with a horrible finish. Now it sounds amazing, and all praise is due to Allah. The thing I enjoyed was that I didn’t have to buy a separate case, pcb, and plate to build a similar keyboard. I just used a prebuilt keyboard and customized it to sound the way I liked. And a huge plus is that it is Bluetooth and compatible with multiple devices. Through the process of desoldering the keyboard, i ripped multiple pads and multiple traces, however, still, in the end I just had to use a few wires to fix the pcb. So I think the pcb is very well made. The only reason I ripped the traces and pads was because I was getting frustrated desoldering as I would reapply solder and desolder each pin multiple times and it still wasn’t a clean desolder. So I would try to pull it out with force and in that process I broke nearly 15 things. Around 11 pads and 3 or 4 traces. So please be careful and don’t be impatient like me when desoldering. I would have really preferred it to be stock hot swappable, but I know that they do sell a hot swappable version. A very good keryboard that is very customizable. Just be careful with the pcb as i contacted keychron and they told me that they don’t sell the pcb separately. As for the keyboard, rgb looks stunning, battery life is so long that I never worry about charging it. I don’t think it has ever been below 70%. And I rarely ever have it plugged in. I also don’t usually have it on rgb mode though since rgb isn’t my thing.
